module.p:
fiù worth is a masculine common, abstract noun, with the following main uses –
in the prepositional phrase gun fhiù worthless, trashy, trivial
the construction chan fhiù ... not be worth ...
the focusing construction fiù (agus) even

The prepositional phrase gun fhiù worthless, trashy, trivial is generally used as a noun modifier –
A dh’aindeoin cràbhaidh is dealais chithear roinn de’n mhór-shluagh a gluasad mar nach robh buaidh a’ chreidimh Chriosdail ach rud gun fhiù.
[...] as if the influence of the Christian faith is only a trivial thing.
Faodaidh e bhith gu bheil an stuth a bheir tearmuinn bho’n lasair a’ fàgail an aodaich beagan nas cruaidhe anns an làimh, gu h-àraidh roimh a nighe, agus gu bheil e gu tric nas daoire, is nach faodar stuth todhair a chur air, ach gu dé tha sin ach nithean gun fhiù an taca ri beatha caileig?
[...] But what are those but trivial things compared with a girl’s life? td. 347
’Se a’ chiad riatanas an ceòl a thoirt a follais; chan eil mathas idir a bhith deasbad air ceistean beaga gun fhiù.
The first requirement is to bring the music into the open; there is no good at all in debating small, trivial problems. td. 93
sgrìobhaidhean gun fhiù
worthless writings td. 190

Examples of the construction chan fhiù ... (past cha b’ fhiù ...) not be worth –
Chan fhiù e deich sgillinn.
It’s not worth 10p. td. 190
Chan fhiù i a màthair.
She’s not worth (ie. the equal of) her mother (ie. the woman her mother was). td. 190
Chan fhiù e dad.
It’s not worth anything. td. 306

module.h: fiù (agus) as a focusing construction – even
module.p:
As the subject of bi with negative scope – na bi fiù agus ... –
basic examples –
Cha robh fiù is pìos arain air fhàgail.
There wasn’t even / as much as a piece of bread left. td. 190
Cha robh fiù ’s seithear ann.
There wasn’t even a chair. td. 59
the agus is sometimes dropped –
Co-dhiùbh, chunnaic mi esan – an t-aonaran – pìos air falbh ’s e ’na shuidhe leis fhèin. Cha robh e dèanamh càil ach a’ suidhe. Cha robh fiù slat aige.
Anyway, I saw him – the loner – a small distance away sitting on his own. He was doing nothing but sit there. He didn’t even have a [fishing] rod. td. 4
Cha robh fiù fiamh a’ ghàire air aghaidh mhòir, bhrògaich an Urramaich. Cha robh e cleachdte ri còmhradh faoin.
There was not even the hint of a smile on the Reverend’s big, sturdy face. He was not accustomed to flippant conversation. td. 6
gun fiù (agus) ... without even ... –
“A bheil guth air Fionnghal?” “Tha,” ars ise gun fiù faileas imcheiste, agus phut i gu sùgrach air falbh mi. “Innisidh mi dhut mun deidhinn uaireigin.”
“Is there mention of Flora?” “Yes,” she said without even a shadow of doubt, and she pushed me away playfully. “I’ll tell you about them sometime.” td. 39

As the subject or object of other verbs with negative scope –
basic examples –
“Nach eil e glè iongantach nach tàing fiù litir-taing bho Theàrlach gu Fionnghal. Bha e beò fada an dèidh dhaibh dealachadh.”
“Isn’t it amazing that not even a letter of thanks came from Charles to Flora. He was alive long after they went their separate ways.” td. 39
Chan fheum e fiù ’s deoch.
It doesn’t even need a drink. td. 306 It does not need a drink.
preposed examples –
Cha do chòrd am boireannach ud rium idir. Fiù teine cha robh i toirt dhomh air an oidhche, ’s aig an tigh bhithinn a’ faighinn botal teth ’na mo leabaidh.
I didn’t like that woman at all. She didn’t even give me a fire at night, and at home I would get a hot water bottle in my bed. td. 65
introducing an embedded question –
Chan eil fhios agam fiù dè an t-ainm a th’ort.
I don’t even know what your name is. td. 306
(na) ... fiù agus aon ... (not) even a single ... –

ul.li:
negative scope –
Cha robh fiù ’s aon chuileag ri fhaicinn.
There wasn’t a single fly to be seen. td. 306
... ach fiù ’s aon daoine cha do nochd e fhèin ...
... but not even one person showed himself ... td. 306

positive scope –
Tha an t-ùghdar a’ cuimhneachadh dhuinn gu robh litreachadh a’ Phrionnsa Teàrlaich glè chearbach, agus fhuair e beachd bho eachdraiche a’ dearbhadh cho luachmhor ’s a bhiodh fiù aon litir bhon Phrionnsa gu Fionnghal.
The author reminds us that Prince Charles’ spelling was very clumsy, and he got an opinion from a historian attesting how valuable even one letter from the Prince to Flora would be. td. 38

module.p: As the final element in a list ... agus fiù (’s) ... and even ... –

ul.li:
basic examples –
Fhuair iad soithichean agus fiù ’s àirneis-taighe.
They got dishes and even furniture. td. 306

dropping the first agus –
Tha Oifig a’ Phuist air céis post-adhair Gàidhlig a chur a-mach mu thràth agus tha iad a’ bruidhinn air ainm Gàidhlig a chur air na carbaidean ùra aca – co-dhiù air a’ Ghàidhealtachd. Tha fiù’s rudan mar seo feumail ach faodaidh iad a bhith ’nam mealladh cuideachd. Tha móran de’n t-seòrsa seo a dh’fhaodar a dheanamh fhathast – mar stampaichean, postairean, fiù’s òrduighean-puist.
The Post Office has already sent out Gaelic airmail envelopes and they are talking about a Gaelic name to put on their new vans – at least in the Highlands. Even things like this are useful but they can be deceptive as well. Many things of this kind can be done yet – like stamps, posters, even postal orders. td. 17
Dheanadh e diofar mór do mheas dhaoine air a’ Ghàidhlig nam biodh i air a cleachdadh air tafaidean-malairt leithid postairean, sanasan, cùnntasan, clàir-bùtha, fiù’s rudan mar seic-leabhraichean.
It would make a big difference to people’s respect for Gaelic if it were used on commercial [things?] like posters, adverts, accounts, sign boards, even things like cheque books. td. 22

with a definite noun the second agus is usually dropped –
Bha a h-uile càil luachmhor a bha am broinn an taigh air a ghoid: dà thelebhisean, bhidio, dà rèidio, reacòrdair, seudan, camanan goilf agus fiù an cleoc mòr a bha anns an talla.
Everything valuable that had been inside the house had been stolen: two televisions, a video recorder, two radios, a tape recorder, jewellery, gold clubs and even the big clock that had been in the hall. td. 14

with negative scope nor even –
Nuair a dhùisg mi bha mi anns an leabaidh agus cha robh sgeul oirrese. Cha robh sgeul air mo sheacaid a bharrachd, no mo cheas ’s fiù an t-uaireadair a bha air caol mo dhùirn.
When I awoke I was in the bed and there was no sign of her. There was no sign of my jacket either, nor my case nor even the watch that had been on my wrist. td. 48

progressive –
Theab mi an dorus fhosgladh ’s a dhol a-steach air a’ ghuth thàmh do’n bhothan. Cha robh mi fiù a’ cluinntinn duine a’ tarraing anail.
I nearly opened the door and quietly entered the house. I couldn’t even hear anyone drawing breath. td. 22
Is dé a bha an t-aonaran a’ smaoineachadh ’s an ceòl ud a’ dol air adhart glé fhaisg air a bhothan? An robh e slaodadh plaidichean mun cuairt a chinn gus am bódhradh iad an ceòl no an do ràinig e rìoghachd cho fad air falbh bho’n cheòl ud ’s nach robh e fiù a’ dèanamh dragh dha.
And what was the loner thinking with that music going on so near to the hut? Was he pulling blankets around his head to dampen the sound or had he reached a kingdom so far away from that music that it wasn’t even bothering him. td 57

infinitival –
Bha e duilich dhomh fiù gal an latha bha mi aig a h-uaigh.
It was hard for me to even cry the day I was at her grave. td. 18
Dè as urrainn dhomh a dhèanamh an seo? Chan e dotair a th’ annam, chan aithne dhomh taigh a thogail, chan aithne dhomh fiù talamh àiteachadh.
What can I do here? I’m not a doctor, I don’t know how to build a house, I don’t even know how to cultivate land. td. 20

module.p:
More complicated examples –
Bha fhios a’m nach robh càil a mhath dhomh cuideachadh iarraidh air Dougie. No air Murchadh Mór. No air Cairstìona. Chaidh mi troimh gach ainm a bh’anns a’ bhaile ’s cha do smaoinich mi air duine a chuidicheadh mi. Cha robh fiù nach do smaoinich mi air athair Seonag. Smaoinich mi air Coinneach Iain cuideachd.
I went through every name that was in the village and couldn’t think of anyone who would help me. I even thought of Jean’s father. td. 72
Nuair a chunnaic mi a dhealbh air an teilidh, ’s ann ri aghaidh an duine a mharbh mi a bha mi coimhead. Abair gun chlisg mi. Chuir mi fios gu mo bhràthair, a bha na àrd-oifigear sa phrìosan aig an àm, agus lorg e gur e leth-aon a bha san fhear-poileataics. Fiù nach robh an aon tatù air a ghàirdean agus bhiodh e tric an Glaschu a’ cèilidh air a bhràthair agus a’ cleachdadh Fiat a bhràthar.
He even had the same tattoo on his arm [...]
Cha do rinn iad fiù agus sùil a thoirt oirnn.
They didn’t even / so much as look at us. td. 191 They didn’t give us an eye.
Tha Oifig a’ Phuist air céis post-adhair Gàidhlig a chur a-mach mu thràth agus tha iad a’ bruidhinn air ainm Gàidhlig a chur air na carbaidean ùra aca – co-dhiù air a’ Ghàidhealtachd. Tha fiù’s rudan mar seo feumail ach faodaidh iad a bhith ’nam mealladh cuideachd. Tha móran de’n t-seòrsa seo a dh’fhaodar a dheanamh fhathast – mar stampaichean, postairean, fiù’s òrduighean-puist.
The Post Office has already sent out Gaelic airmail envelopes and they are talking about a Gaelic name to put on their new vans – at least in the Highlands. Even things like this are useful but they can be deceptive as well. Many things of this kind can be done yet – like stamps, posters, even postal orders. td. 17 English translation? subject of bi but positive polarity.
An diugh chan eil duine nas toilichte na tha a’ mhór-chuid de’n luchd-teagaisg a bhith cur na Gàidhlig an céill còmhla ris a’ chloinn, gu h-àraid nuair a chì iad gu bheil luchd-stiùiridh an fhoghluim leotha, agus gu bheil iad ri fairbheanadh gu bheil fiù’s Dun Eideann ri cur sùim anns na tha iad a’ deanamh troimh an dà chànan.
Today nobody is happier than the majority of teachers [...], especially when they see that the directors of education are with them, and that they are [...] that even Edinburgh is to give attention to what they are doing through the two languages. td. 33
